With changing docks and break-out zones, the capital's coolest workout spots mean it's easy to keep fit on the job, says Phoebe Luckhurst Monday 20 March 2017 12:06 GMT Click to followES Lifestyle Boom Cycle's new work area Daniel Hambury/Stella Pictures 
In London, every hour is accounted for. Schedules have scant wiggle room: you have choreographed your day with forensic pendantry, right down to the time it will take you to descend the escalator, shoot four stops north on the Northern line, and then ascend the second escalator and meet whomever you cannot be late for. 
Accordingly, this makes spontaneity difficult, and balance harder. For example, in order to work and exercise, you must leave the office at precisely 6.14pm, in order to make your HIIT class, or gazump the hordes who also want to pace the same treadmill as you do this evening. Furthermore, all this zipping around the city is so exhausting that you barely have the energy to exercise anyway. 
What every Londoner needs is a one-stop shop: somewhere that multitasks deftly, offering both workspace and studios (as well as food). Moreover, ideally it will also be somewhere you can wait to receive guests, if you are also trying to balance an equation that includes some socialising. If it all sounds slightly institutionalised, suspend judgement till you consider the boutique options that are offering just this mixture. 
The first is Boom Cycle, which is expanding into its third site in the Battersea Power Station development this summer — offering two spin studios, a large juice café and, crucially, “charge points everywhere”, explains its co-founder, Hilary Rowland, who tells me her plan is for visitors to use the space as an pseudo-office before and after classes. She was inspired by her crew at the Holborn studio, most of whom are part-time instructors, but use the space as a full-time office. “Half our team is in there all day,” she laughs. Self-defence for women: Five Krav Maga moves everyone should know Boom Cycle founder Hilary Gilbert on London's spinning obsession 
They begin building the site in a few weeks: the finished iteration will be 4,700 sq ft and include 70 bikes across two studios. So the site can accommodate plenty of multitasking worker bees, and the workspace vibes will likely make a convincing difference to those people who wrestle with the guilt of leaving the office (or home office) early in order to make a class. The answer is, clearly, just bed in for the whole day — hell, maybe this way you can manage two sessions (energy permitting). 
Its location within the Battersea Power Station development is fortuitous: Rowland explains that Boom also plans to arrange drink and food deals with other brands in the area, which is certainly another incentive to reshape your day so it takes place within the orbit of the studio. Virgin Active Mayfair 
There’s more: if you forget your kit, Rowland also promises an extensive outfitters offering with activewear for both men and women, and if you want to charge your mind as well as recharge your laptop, she also says that Boom will be holding “lifestyle talks and events” in the space. “And parties.” So it caters for the evening too, then: a real one-stop shop. 20 male fitness influencers to follow on Instagram - in pictures 20 male fitness influencers to follow on Instagram - in pictures 1/20 Joe Wicks (@thebodycoach) 
“Body Coach” Joe Wicks is on a mission to educate his 1.7 million followers on ways to be healthy, strong, and #LeanIn15. The wildly popular fitness guru-turned-other posts deliciously healthy meals, transformation photos of his clients and even the occasional selfie (swoon!) Joe Wicks 2/20 Kemo Marriott (@kemo.marriott) 
This high-tech trainer pushes his clients (oftentimes business executives, according to his website) to be their best, using heart rate and brain wave trackers to watch their progress. Marriott founded his own health coaching service, but also runs a male-exclusive fitness club on Facebook, where his followers can compete in weekly challenges. Follow for intense “fitspo” and gorgeous, magazine-ready images. Kenneth Gallarzo 3/20 Curtis WIlliams (@curtiswilliams17) 
Former American football player turned Under Armour athlete is a performance coach for the fittest celebs, like singer-songwriter Ne-yo, and intersperses his impressive fitness photos with inspirational quotes, like, “You can’t do big things if you’re distracted by small things”, or “Appreciate what you have while you have it.” @fitflexjuli 4/20 Ken Gallarzo (@progressive_calisthenics) 
This calisthenics instructor is #goals, and his feed of Instagram videos shows it. Follow along for gravity-defying moves from Gallarzo, couple exercises with his super strong girlfriend, and creative videos from the inspiring clients partaking in his 60-day program. Ken Gallarzo 5/20 Antoine Dunn (@pt_dunn) 
When you see Jourdan Dunn strut her fit bod down the runway, you can thank her fitness guru brother. Antoine Dunn whips his clients into shape through boxing classes. Antoine Dunn 6/20 Brett Hoebel (@bretthoebel) 
Trainer on American reality TV show “Biggest Loser” may kick his contestants into gear, but that doesn’t mean he can’t inspire others. Join his 15k followers (including the Victoria’s Secret supermodels he trains!) for inspiration that will inspire you get off your sofa and get started. 7/20 James Duigan (@jamesduigan) 
Duigan is the author of “Clean and Lean Diet” books, and posts gorgeous photos of food, coffee and uplifting quotes from his Bodyism Cafe location in Notting Hill. The lifestyle company was founded in South Kensington, but includes wellness clubs all over the world. Follow for a little pep in your step and inspiration to be your best, healthiest self. James Duigan 8/20 Dylan Werner (@dylanwerneryoga) 
This body-twisting yogi’s photos might make your muscles ache just by looking at them, but the gorgeous feed of well-edited pictures is well worth a follow. At least 416k other people think so. Namaste! Dylan Werner 9/20 Noah Ohlsen (@nohlsen) 
Ohlsen is a CrossFit Games Athlete, and inspires others through his own work at the gym he owns in Miami. The only thing cuter than this smiley American weight lifter? His adorable gym rat, er, Golden Retriever! Noah Ohlsen 10/20 Gunnar Peterson (@gunnarfitness) 
Behind almost every enviable Hollywood body is this American personal trainer (We see you, Khloe Kardashian!) Peterson has not only trained tons of film and television stars, but also professional athletes of almost every sport. His Instagram is more modest, however, with fitness photos interspersed photos of his adorable son, dogs and inspirational quotes jotted on the walls of his gym. Gunnar Peterson 11/20 Calvin Royal III (@calvinroyaliii) 
This American Ballet Theatre dancer will you give you major muscle envy with his posts, which often include professional photos to promote his ballets. Royal III makes flying through the air seem easy, but his chiseled figure says otherwise. Nisian Hughs 12/20 Bradley Simmons (@bradleysimmons) 
Simmonds is a London-based trainer who will make you want to hit the gym ASAP. The former footballer uses Instagram as a marketing platform, showcasing some of his clients — top athletes, A-list celebrities and fitness-loving Londoners alike. Bradley Simmons 13/20 Adam Rosante (@adamrosante) 
This performance coach believes weight training and yoga go hand in hand, proving on his Instagram account why yogis should be lifting. “Strong bi's help boost your performance on key compound movements, not to mention limit your potential for a number of injuries”, he writes in a post. Adam Rosante 14/20 Bret Contreras (@bretcontreras1) 
The self-proclaimed “Glute Guy” considers himself the world’s foremost expert on glute training. So if you’re looking to tighten your ... you know ... head to this page for expert advice (and lots of statistics!) about the science of the sport. Bret Contreras 15/20 Hunter Cook (@hunterfitness) 
This California-based personal trainer and yogi wows his Instagram audience with his flexibility, strength and adorable pet bulldog. Hunter Cook 16/20 Ricky Warren (@rix.official) 
Warren is a calisthenics pro, who also has a focus on training through mixed martial arts. He founded Bodyweight Gurus in London to hold workshops and spread his method to others in the UK. “I love all forms of movement”, he wrote on his website. “The human body is the most complicated and intelligent machine we know of.” Kemo Marriott 17/20 Luke Worthington (@lukewtraining) 
This London-based trainer also leads trainer education at Third Space in Covent Garden, where he puts his head (and his hard-earned body) to work. “We live in a very over-stimulated world”, he told us in March. “By being a little more selective about the stimulation people are getting, you can manage pain, stress levels, how they sleep and how their body moves. That’s when it gets useful for non-athletes.” Third Space Trainers 18/20 Keoni Hudoba (@keonihudoba) 
In the craze of indoor cycling classes, this trainer stands out. Hudoba founded Cyc Fitness in the U.S., is an Under Armour trainer and serves as an inspiration to many, since he started out in fitness during his own major body transformation (Hudoba lost about half his body weight!). His Instagram feed is pretty brill, incorporating his love for photography with inspiring others to be fit, healthy and happy. Keoni Hudoba 19/20 Joshua Holmes (@joshuaholmes) 
This ultra-marathoner takes his 34.7K followers alongside his trail runs, races and training exercises. Follow for gorgeous trail run views that will make you want to venture outside the gym for your next sweat. Joshua Holmes 20/20 Mike Marchese (@upyourfitness) 
Creator of BAR (Bodyweight Athletic Regime) Marchese travels the world to teach new clients his gravity-defying approach to calisthenics. Mike Marchese 
Seemingly, it’s setting the tone for a new movement. Third Space’s cavernous gym in Canary Wharf has an on-site restaurant-slash-lounge, the Pearson Room, which is sort of like having a members’ club lounge inside a members’-only gym. There are plump sofas and low tables, which is comfier than your real desk. Lithe sportsmen and women sit in various states of athleisure, stroking the illuminated keys of MacBook Airs; half an hour later, find them flexing across the climbing wall, collecting a team for a game in the capacious sports hall, or beating their fists to pulp on the plump punch-bags. The new fitness class where you can burn 1,000 calories in one session 
Virgin Active’s newest club on the Strand has a huge lounge, free wi-fi, Apple computers, charge points and papers — and many of its other clubs, including the Kensington gym, have smaller versions of the same set-up. Emails are more manageable after plunging into the glassy depths of a pool for a cool down. Elite gym Equinox has wi-fi everywhere, and generous tables in its café for stretching out to work. Studiedly sparse Hackney studio Blok doesn’t go in for decoration, but it does have high workspaces and a long table in its on-site café (which will also serve you bone broth for restoring brain cells after a depleting session). Many freelancing east Londoners prefer it to the showy hubbub of Shoreditch House or a cold press coffee joint. To keep fit you need to work at it. More about:
